text: In the slow-release replication cycle, a filamentous phage produces phage particles without lysing the cell.
Progeny phages must exit the host cell, and then reach new host cells to infect.
Various kinds of host molecules can membrane proteins and complexes (OmpF and TolC), and flagellar proteins.
Phage recombines by re-joining the ends of its genome and enters the lytic cycle.
The host continues to reproduce itself, but more slowly than uninfected cells do because many of its resources are being used to make phages.
The empty capsid is termed a “ghost” because of its pale appearance in an electron micrograph.
What is remarkable about this fungus-plant pair is that each partner confers thermal tolerance (heat resistance) on the other (Fig. 1).
Together, the plant and fungus grow at temperatures as high as 65°C—which commonly occur in the vicinity of Yellowstone’s thermal springs.
Components usually “self-assemble”; that is, the joining of their parts is favored thermodynamically.

Redman and Roossinck identified a mysterious virus in a fungus, Curvularia protuberata, which grows associated with a panic grass, Dichanthelium lanuginosum, in as an “endophyte” within the vasculature of the grass—a highly common form of symbiosis (discussed in Chapter 21).
